cards.back: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing some end.
A way of representing information using only two options.
The smallest unit of data in computing represented by a 1 in binary.
A data type that has two possible values (usually denoted true and false).
An error in a program that prevents the program from running as expected.
A group of binary digits or bits (usually eight) operated on as a unit.
A collection of data duplicating original values stored elsewhere or computed earlier, where the original data is expensive to fetch or compute relative to reading the cache.
A program that translates code written in a high-level programming language to machine code.
A particular way of organizing data in a computer so that it can be used effectively.
An organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.
The process of finding and fixing errors in a computer program.
A piece of code that can be called over and over.
A software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development.
A whole number; a number that is not a fraction.
A sequence of instructions that is continually repeated until a certain condition is reached.
A self-contained entity that consists of both data and procedures to manipulate the data.
A programming language object that stores the memory address of another value located in computer memory.
A programming technique where a function calls itself.
A collection of instructions that enable the user to interact with a computer, its hardware, or perform tasks.
The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs in a language.
A storage location and an associated symbolic name (an identifier), which contains some known or unknown quantity of information referred to as a value.
The process of finding and fixing issues within a computer program.
A block of organized, reusable code that is used to perform a single, related action.
A feature of a programming language, which performs different computations or actions depending on whether a programmer-specified boolean condition evaluates to true or false.
A data structure consisting of a collection of elements, each identified by at least one array index or key.
A programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data, in the form of fields, and code, in the form of procedures.
A blueprint for creating objects (a particular data structure), providing initial values for state (member variables or attributes), and implementations of behavior (member functions or methods).
A mechanism in which one class acquires the properties (methods and fields) of another class.
A shared boundary across which two separate components of a computer system exchange information.
The bundling of data with the methods that operate on that data, or the restricting of direct access to some of an object's components.
The provision of a single interface to entities of different types or the use of a single symbol to represent multiple different types.
A measure of the amount of time and/or space required by an algorithm for an input of a given size (n).
The process in which a function calls itself directly or indirectly.
The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs in that language.
A named variable passed into a function. Parameter variables are used to import arguments into functions.
The actual value that is passed to the function (as input), when it is called.
A collection of non-volatile resources used by computer programs, often to develop software.
Any collection of code, possibly with comments, written using a human-readable programming language, usually as plain text.
A software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development.
The process by which a computer or virtual machine performs the instructions of a computer program.
The process in which source code is translated to machine code.
